title: 112_hr3012
content: The Act titled "Fairness for High-Skilled Immigrants Act of 2011" imposes a numerical limitation on visas from any single foreign state. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to make changes to visa allocation and numerical limitations for high-skilled immigrants. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to change visa allocation and numerical limitations for high-skilled immigrants, including special rules for countries exceeding the visa limit in any fiscal year. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to change visa allocation and numerical limitations for high-skilled immigrants, including special rules for countries exceeding the visa limit in any fiscal year. Visa numbers will be allocated to natives based on specific ratios to ensure fair distribution. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to change visa allocation and numerical limitations for high-skilled immigrants, including special rules for countries exceeding the visa limit in any fiscal year. Visa numbers will be allocated to natives based on specific ratios to ensure fair distribution. The amendments made under section 203(a) of the Chinese Student Protection Act of 1992 will take effect on September 30, 2011, and apply to fiscal years starting from 2012. For fiscal years 2012 and 2013, specific percentages of immigrant visas under section 203(b) of the Immigration and Nationality Act will be allotted to natives of certain countries to ensure fair distribution. For fiscal years 2012 and 2013, specific percentages of immigrant visas under section 203(b) of the Immigration and Nationality Act will be allotted to natives of certain countries to ensure fair distribution. In fiscal years 2013 and 2014, 10 percent of immigrant visas under each paragraph will be allocated to immigrants from states not among the top two with the highest numbers of visas in the previous fiscal year. For fiscal year 2014, 10 percent of immigrant visas under section 203(b) of the Immigration and Nationality Act will be allotted to natives of states not among the top two with the highest numbers of visas in fiscal year 2012. In fiscal year 2012, the number of visas available to natives of any single foreign state or dependent area is limited to 25 percent or 2 percent, respectively. Unreserved immigrant visas for fiscal years 2012, 2013, and 2014 should not exceed 85 percent. In fiscal years 2012, 2013, and 2014, unreserved immigrant visas should not exceed 85 percent for natives of any single foreign state. If visas are unused, they may be issued in subsequent years to prevent a total visa shortage. In fiscal years 2012, 2013, and 2014, if the total number of immigrant visas available under certain sections would not be issued, visas may be issued in the remainder of the fiscal year without restrictions. Rules for chargeability apply in determining the foreign state an alien is chargeable to. The House of Representatives passed the bill on November 29, 2011. Karen L. Haas is the Clerk.
